GB Cindroes are found in the United Kingdom, specifically in Scotland, where they were formed during the Pleistocene epoch, which lasted from 2.6 million to 9,700 years ago. ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞, ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§°‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§á‡§ü ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§è‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø ‡§π‡•Å‡§à, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ These cinder cones were created by the eruption of lava from the volcano' s crater, and the resulting ash and debris were then solidified into the distinctive cobble-like formations that we see today.
